comment: Black prepares ...Nc5 by for the moment preventing b2-b4. White, in turn, is ready to evict the knight from c5 by Ne1-d3, or to exchange it. Of course, I could have exchanged on d4 earlier, but when the white bishop is developed at e2 I do not like to take on d4.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as it highlights the possibility of exchanging on d4 earlier, which could have prevented the positional issue caused by the knight on c5.

reformulated: Black played Pawn to a5, which doesn't contribute significantly to the game. It temporarily stops White's plan of pushing the knight to c5 and taking control of the board. White has options to challenge Black's knight, either by moving it to d3 or considering a trade. Although exchanging on d4 could have been beneficial earlier, the presence of the white bishop on e2 makes taking on d4 less appealing.

comment: It used to be thought that, when Black's knight reached c5, he achieved a good position. After all, I was not the first and not the tenth person to play the King's Indian. It was employed by Capablanca and the English Champion Yates, and it was played by Reti, Euwe, Chigorin and even Tarrasch. But it should be realised that this is a good position only compared with the Queen's Gambit, where you are down on your knees, awaiting the invasion of a knight at e5, the doubling of rooks, and so on.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake by comparing the current position with a superior alternative (Queen's Gambit), highlighting the inferiority of the present move.

reformulated: Lisitsyn, as White, made an aggressive move. Although Black's knight reaching c5 is traditionally seen as strong, it's crucial to consider the current position and potential weaknesses. This move may not be optimal, as it can lead to vulnerabilities such as a knight invasion at e5 or rook doubling, which could pressure Black significantly.

comment: Georgy Lisitsyn was a very strong player, who wrote three excellent books - on the opening, middlegame, and endgame. I confidently played 12...Ng4, and was very surprised by the exchange of first one bishop for a knight, and then the other.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake because it acknowledges the loss of material and the surprising nature of the exchange, which likely led to a disadvantageous position for the player.

comment: A brilliant decision by White - he captured with his bishop (!) on c5 and then played f2-f4. I found myself in a very difficult position, and did not know what to do. In general, at that time I was not afraid of ending up in difficulties, as I always believed I would find something! That was also the case in the present game.
